questions.title: Half-Life of Radioactive Sample
questions.questionText:
There are \(n\) number of radioactive nuclei in a sample at a time \(t\). If \(n'\) number of \( eta\) particles are emitted in the next two seconds from the sample, then the half-life of the sample is (\(t_{half\ life} \gg 2	ext{ sec}\)).
(A) \( rac{n'}{2}\)
(B) \(0.693 	imes  rac{2n}{n'}\)
(C) \(0.693 	imes \ln\left( rac{2n}{n'}ight)\)
(D) \(0.693 	imes  rac{n}{n'}\)
questions.solution:
The number of radioactive nuclei decayed in the next two seconds is \(n'\).
The rate of decay \( = -\frac{dN}{dt} \approx \frac{n'}{2} = \lambda n\)
where \(\lambda\) is the decay constant.\n\(\implies \lambda = \frac{n'}{2n}\)
Half-life is \(t_{1/2} = \frac{0.693}{\lambda} = \frac{0.693}{\frac{n'}{2n}} = 0.693 \times \frac{2n}{n'}\)
questions.hint: Use the radioactive decay law: \(-\frac{dN}{dt} = \lambda N\), where \(\lambda\) is the decay constant and \(N\) is the number of radioactive nuclei.  Also, remember the relationship between half-life and the decay constant.
methodOfSolving: Determine the decay rate (dN/dt) from the given information.
Relate the decay rate to the number of radioactive nuclei n and the decay constant \(\lambda\) using the decay law.
Use the relation \(t_{1/2} = \frac{0.693}{\lambda}\) to find the half-life.
